metadata.title: High-performance addition reaction of methyl acrylate and methanol for the preparation of Methyl 3-methoxypropionate on NiO/MgO catalyst

Fig. 1 Schematic representation of NiO/MgO synthesis. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 (a) XRD pattern of the MgO, CeO/MgO, CoO/MgO, and NiO/MgO; (b) XPS spectra of Ni 2p for NiO/MgO; (c) FT-IR spectra of NiO/MgO; (d) Nitrogen sorption isotherms of the neat MgO and NiO/MgO with pore size distributions inside. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Catalytic performance of the MgO, CeO/MgO, CoO/MgO, and NiO/MgO for the synthesis of methyl 3-methoxypropionate by addition of methyl acrylate and methanol (a); Catalytic performance of the NiO/MgO at various NiO content (b); Catalytic performance of the NiO/MgO-3 at different reaction temperatures (c); Catalytic performance of the NiO/MgO-4 at different reaction pressure (d); different reaction times (e); different MA content (f); different catalysts amount (g); The catalytic performance of the NiO/MgO-4 in the cycle experiment (200 ℃, 2 MPa, 8 h) (h). If not specified, the reaction conditions: 150 ℃, 2 MPa, 8 h, MA/MeOH = 1:4, and 0.4 g catalyst. Fig. 3 Scheme 1 Detailed mechanism of sequential product formation from MA to MMP based on the Michael addition reaction [33]. Scheme 1 Scheme 2 Plausible mechanism for the addition reaction of MA with methanol. Scheme 2 High-performance addition reaction of methyl acrylate and methanol for the preparation of Methyl 3-methoxypropionate on NiO/MgO catalyst Xiaoke Li a b c Xiuyun Liu b c Zhou Lu a ⁎ Guoqiang Xu b c ⁎⁎ a Chemistry and Chemical Engineering College of Qingdao University, Qingdao 266071, China Chemistry and Chemical Engineering College of Qingdao University Qingdao 266071 China Chemistry and Chemical Engineering College of Qingdao University, Qingdao 266071, China b Qingdao Institute of Bioenergy and Bioprocess Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Qingdao 266101, China Qingdao Institute of Bioenergy and Bioprocess Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences Qingdao 266101 China Qingdao Institute of Bioenergy and Bioprocess Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Qingdao 266101, China c Shandong Energy Institute, Qingdao 266101, Shandong, China Shandong Energy Institute Qingdao Shandong 266101 China Shandong Energy Institute, Qingdao 266101, Shandong, China ⁎ Corresponding author. ⁎⁎ Corresponding author at: Qingdao Institute of Bioenergy and Bioprocess Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Qingdao 266101, China. Qingdao Institute of Bioenergy and Bioprocess Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences Qingdao 266101 China. In this study, Methyl 3-methoxypropionate (MMP) was formed from the addition reaction of methyl acrylate (MA) and methanol using MO/MgO (M = Ce, Co, Ni) catalysts, which were prepared by a direct-mixing method. The prepared catalyst NiO/MgO shows good catalytic activity than that of the CeO/MgO and CoO/MgO under the same conditions. The characterization and catalytic activity evaluation indicate that the NiO content of NiO/MgO has a significant effect on the catalytic activity of the addition reaction by changing the acid-base properties of the catalyst. The synergistic effect of acidic and basic sites contributes to the addition reaction. The optimal reaction temperature and pressure for NiO/MgO on this addition reaction is 200 ℃ and 2 MPa, respectively (over 90% selectivity to MMP). The cycle test indicates that the NiO/MgO catalyst is highly recyclable. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Methyl 3-methoxypropionate Addition reaction NiO/MgO catalyst Acid-base synergistic effect High efficiency catalysis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction As an important organic synthesis intermediate and organic solvent, methyl 3-methoxypropionate (MMP) is widely used in the electronics industry, coating industry and organic synthesis [1–4]. The β-alkoxycarbonyl group of MMP is ubiquitous in natural products and biologically active compounds [5]. It is usually synthesized by aldol condensation reaction and subsequent hydroxyl alkylation reaction [6]. In addition, Michael addition reaction of alcohols to double bonds provides a direct and general method [7]. However, the formation of carbon-oxygen bonds through the Michael addition reaction is still challenging due to the potential oligomerization of the receptor, reversibility and the inherent energy aspects of the process [8]. At present, MMP is mainly obtained by the addition reaction of methyl acrylate (MA) and methanol. Sodium methoxide is the most commonly used catalyst for the addition reaction of methanol and MA in previous studies [9]. For the catalyst sodium methoxide, the yield of MMP formed from methanol and MA could reach more than 97% [1]. But there are a lot of shortcomings for the reaction process catalyzed by using sodium methoxide, such as high price of sodium methoxide, acid neutralization process after reaction and the corrosion of the chemical reactor during the neutralization process [2]. Since that the catalyst sodium methoxide needs to be neutralized by acid after the reaction, the sodium methoxide is hardly to be reused, and the produced sodium salt would be wasted [10]. Additionally, MA is prone to polymerization during the reaction and thus decrease the selectivity of MMP, then MA needs to be added slowly during the reaction. Therefore, the reaction process will be lengthened. Overall, a new highly efficient catalyst for the addition reaction of MA and methanol to MMP needs to be discovered and the proper reaction conditions need to be investigated. Metal oxides represent one of the most important and widely employed categories of solid catalysts [11]. Among the metal oxide catalysts, transition metals occupy a predominant place owing to their low cost of production, easy regeneration and selective action [11]. Metal oxides are utilized both for their acid-base and redox properties [12,13]. Michael addition reactions were studied by Figueras and co-workers at room temperature, using a magnesium-lanthanum mixed oxide, and obtained a very good yield [14]. And Ni, Co, and Ce have taken more attention due to their excellent activity in reactions [15]. The enhanced activity of the composite catalysts is mainly attributed to the synergistic effect between the metal oxide [16]. Considering that the metal oxide catalysts have acid-base properties and are expected to show catalytic activity for the preparation of MMP by the addition reaction of MA and methanol, MO/MgO (M = Ce, Co, Ni) were prepared by direct-mixing method and used for the preparation of MMP in this work. And it has not been reported before for this reaction to be catalyzed by metal oxide compounds. The prepared NiO/MgO shows better catalytic activity (a 73.9% conversion of MA and a 75.9% selectivity of MMP under the reaction of 150 ℃, 2 MPa) than that of the CeO/MgO and CoO/MgO under the same conditions. And all the prepared catalysts were much more active than MgO. The physical-chemical properties of the prepared catalysts were comprehensively analyzed by XRD, BET, XPS, FT-IR, NH3/CO2-TPD methods. The combination of catalyst characterization and catalytic activity evaluation indicates that the good performance of NiO/MgO may due to the acid-base synergistic effect. The reaction conditions were optimized and the stability of the catalyst was evaluated under the optimal reaction conditions. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials The following chemicals were used without further purification. Cobaltic oxide (Co2O3) was purchased from Tianjin BASF Co., Ltd. Methanol (CH3OH, AR), methyl acrylate (MA, AR), magnesium oxide (MgO, AR), nickel oxide (NiO, AR), ceric dioxide (CeO2, AR) and ethyl butyrate (C6H12O2, AR) were supplied by Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The MO/MgO (M = Ce, Co, Ni) catalysts were synthesized by a direct-mixing method. Take NiO/MgO as an example ( Fig. 1), 15 g MgO and 3 g NiO was dispersed in 160 mL water firstly, then the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 6 h with a rate of 300 rpm. After that, the mixture was stirred in an oil bath at 75 ℃ for 6 h. The cake was filtered and washed with ethanol after condensation. The obtained powder was dried at 100 ℃ for 8 h. Then, the powder was transferred to a tube furnace and heated to 550 ℃ with a heating rate of 3 ℃/min. The calcination was lasted for 8 h in an air atmosphere. The catalyst was labeled NiO/MgO-x (x were related to the mass of NiO added during the preparation of the catalyst). 2.3 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed on a Bruker D8 advanced instrument with a scanning rate of 10°/min and a diffraction angle (2θ) of 5 ∼ 80°. The particle morphology of the catalyst samples were observed by Hitachi S4800 scanning microscope. The catalyst morphology was investigated using transmission electron microscopy (TEM) which was operated on a JEOL F-200 electron microscope at 200 kV. An energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) mapping analysis was performed on a Hitachi S4800. The specific surface area and pore size distribution of the catalysts were analyzed on an ASAP-2020 analyzer, and calculated by Brunaer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method, respectively. The catalysts were tested by Nicolet 6700 FT-IR Spectrometer and AXIS SUPRA + XPS. The acidic sites and basic sites of the catalysts were determined by AutoChem II 2920 programed desorption NH3 (NH3-TPD) instrument and programed desorption CO2 (CO2-TPD) instrument, respectively. The steps of determining the acidic site of the catalyst are as follows: 100 mg of the sample to be tested was slowly load to the U-tube firstly. Then Ar was purged into the U-tube. The U-tube with sample was purged at 500 °C for 1 h firstly and cooled down to 50 °C secondly. After purged with 10 vol% NH3/Ar and stabilized the baseline for 2 h, the temperature was raised to 850 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. 2.4 Catalytic tests The addition reactions of methanol and methyl acrylate (MA) were performed in a batch reactor of 50 mL. Catalyst tests were carried out under 2 MPa N2 pressure. The specific amounts of a catalysts (0.2 ∼ 0.6 g) were placed in the batch reactor with a certain MA amount (5 ∼ 40%), the reactions were performed for 3 ∼ 12 h with a temperature of 50 ∼ 200 °C. The internal standard method was applied in the analytic process, ethyl butyrate was added as an internal standard after reaction. A GC 2010 Plus gas chromatograph (Shimadzu) was utilized to analyze the products. The conversion of MA and selectivity of Methyl 3-methoxypropionate (MMP) were calculated by using internal standard method. The calculation formulas are as follows: MA conversion (%): X M A = m M A ( 0 ) − m M A m M A ( 0 ) × 100 % MMP and MP selectivity (%): S M M P = m M M P m M A ( 0 ) − m M A M M A × M M M P × 100 % MMP yield (%): Y MMP = X MA × S MMP × 100 % Where mMA(0) and mMA are the mass of MA before and after the reaction, respectively. The mMMP is the mass of MMP after reaction; the MMA and MMMP are the molar mass of MA and MMP, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization of MO/MgO catalysts The XRD patterns of MgO, CeO/MgO, CoO/MgO and NiO/MgO all shows obvious peak at 36.9°, 42.9°, 62.3°, 74.6° and 78.6°, which was attributed to the (111), (200), (220), (311), and (222) crystal planes of MgO (PDF#04–0829) ( Fig. 2a). For CeO/MgO and CoO/MgO, the XRD patterns show not only the crystal planes of MgO, but also the crystal planes of CeO2 and Co3O4. For NiO/MgO, the NiO phase (2θ of 37.3°, 43.3°, 62.9°, 75.4° and 79.4°) are related to the (111), (200), (220), (311), and (222) crystal planes of NiO phase (PDF#04–0835), respectively [17,18]. Fig. S4 showed the results of morphological analysis of the metal oxide catalyst using SEM (a ∼ d). It can be observed that the NiO/MgO (Fig. S4) shows flake-shaped structure, and the nanoparticles are evenly distributed on the sample. The EDS mapping analysis (Fig. S4) clearly indicated the distribution range of Mg, O and Ni in the sample, revealing the uniform distribution of Ni in magnesium oxide. It shows that MgO and NiO exists in the form of crystal. XPS spectra of Ni 2p for NiO/MgO (Fig. 2b) indicates that the samples displayed two well-defined peaks at around 872.7 and 854.0 eV, which were ascribed to Ni 2p1/2 and Ni 2p3/2, respectively [19]. The shoulder peak at 856.3 eV was attributed to the Ni2+ species on the surface [20]. The energy difference between Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 splitting was 18.7 eV, which indicates the well-defined symmetry of Ni2+ in oxide form [21]. Mg 2p spectrum of NiO/MgO (Fig. S1b) shows that Mg element mainly exists in the form of MgO [22]. The O 1 s binding energy of NiO/MgO is 530.0 eV (Fig. S1c), indicating that O2- exists on the surface of the catalyst [23]. FT-IR spectra of the NiO/MgO was shown in the Fig. 2c. A broad vibration band is seen in the wave number range 3416 cm−1 due to O-H stretching vibration of surface hydroxyl group [24,25]. And the peaks near 1467 cm−1 originated from the bending vibrations of O-H. In addition, the observed peaks at around 689 cm−1 were assigned to the Mg-O metal-oxygen vibration. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of NiO/MgO (Fig. 2d) presented a type IV N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm with an H4 hysteresis loop, and relative pressure (P/P0) ranged from 0.5 ∼ 1.0, revealing the mesoporous structure of the NiO/MgO. The calculated specific surface area of NiO/MgO is 89.4 m2/g. The corresponding pore size distribution inset Fig. 2d showed the mesoporous size distribution, which is consistent with the above conclusion. Table S1 summarized the specific surface area, pore volume, and mean pore diameter of the neat MgO and NiO/MgO. It was found that the specific surface area of catalysts was obviously decreased compared to the neat MgO, which may be caused by nickel species entering into mesopores and macropores of the MgO. 3.2 Catalytic studies 3.2.1 Catalyst performance for MO/MgO catalysts The catalyst performance of the prepared CeO/MgO, CoO/MgO, and NiO/MgO catalysts for the reaction of methanol and methyl acrylate (MA) were evaluated ( Fig. 3a and Table S2). The MgO was also evaluated for comparison. The conversion of MA for CoO/MgO, CeO/MgO and NiO/MgO were 58.4%, 76.7%, and 73.9%, respectively, significantly higher than that of MgO (39.7%). This indicates that the introduction of metal oxides promoted the transformation of MA. Besides, the selectivity of MMP for CeO/MgO and NiO/MgO were 73.6% and 75.9%, respectively, obviously higher than that of MgO (68.8%). Among these four catalysts, the NiO/MgO performance best with a higher conversion of MA (73.1%) and the highest selectivity of MMP (75.9%). We evaluated the selectivity of the catalyst at the same conversion level and found that the selectivity of NiO/MgO was higher (Table S3). Considering that the NiO/MgO performs better than that of CoO/MgO and CeO/MgO, the NiO/MgO with different ratio of Mg/Ni have been prepared and investigated for the catalytic performance of the reaction of methanol and MA (Fig. 3b and Table S4). The XRD of NiO/MgO with different ratio of Mg/Ni all shows peaks of MgO phase and NiO phase (Fig. S2). As with the decrease of the ratio of Mg/Ni, the conversion of MA increased obviously (from 73.2% to 80.8%). While, the selectivity of MMP increased firstly (from 57% to 75.9%) and then decreased (from 75.9% to 60.8%) with the decrease of the ratio of Mg/Ni. Among the five NiO/MgO catalysts, NiO/MgO-4 catalyst exhibited the best catalytic performance. From the data above, NiO/MgO-3 shows a higher selectivity of MMP than that of NiO/MgO-4, while NiO/MgO-3 shows a lower conversion of MA than that of NiO/MgO-4. This phenomenon roused our curiosity. To take a deep investigation of the structure-function relationship for the addition reaction of methanol and MA on NiO/MgO, NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD were taken to estimate the distribution and total number of acidic sites and basic sites of MgO, NiO/MgO-3 and NiO/MgO-4 (Fig. S5a and S5b, Table S5). The desorption temperature reflected the strength of acidic/basic sites, and the higher desorption temperature means the stronger strength of acidic/basic sites. Generally, the desorption temperature ranged 100 ∼ 300 ℃, 300 ∼ 500 °C and above 500 °C are attributed to weak acidic/basic sites, medium strong acidic/basic sites and strong acidic/basic sites on the catalysts, respectively. For the NH3-TPD curves, the NiO/MgO showed two desorption peaks at 50 ∼ 150 °C and above 550 °C, which were assigned to weak and strong acid, respectively. Weak basic sites are attributed to OH- groups on the catalyst surface. Medium strength basic sites are related to oxygen in Mg2+-O2- pairs. Strong basic sites correspond to isolated O2- anions [25,26]. The amount of acidic sites (both strong acid and weak acid) for NiO/MgO-3 are higher than that of NiO/MgO-4; and the amount of basic sites (both strong base and weak base) for NiO/MgO-4 are higher than that of both NiO/MgO-3 and MgO. The carbon atom connected to the carbonyl (α-C) of MA could lose a proton at the basic site to generate an α-C anion, while MeOH can be activated at the acidic site. For NiO/MgO catalyst, abundant basic sites promote the formation of α-C anions, while insufficient acidic sites inhibit its further conversion to products, resulting in a decrease in its conversion [27]. This indicates that the increase of basic sites would help to promote the transformation of MA [28]. And thus, the NiO/MgO-4 shows a higher conversion of MA than that of NiO/MgO-3. While, the NiO/MgO-3 with a certain amount of acidic sites, may promote the adsorption of MA dispersedly, and thus avoid the polymerization of MA [29,30]. In addition, its rich acidic strength may inhibit the occurrence of side reactions, which made it contribute to higher MMP selectivity [27]. Therefore, the MMP selectivity for NiO/MgO-3 is higher than that of NiO/MgO-4. Basically, the basic sites would help to promote the transformation of MA and the acidic sites could help the formation of MMP [31]. The synergistic effect of acidic sites and basic sites promoted the addition reaction of methanol and MA to MMP [32]. 3.2.2 The effect of different reaction conditions In order to take a deep investigation of the addition reaction of methanol and MA to MMP, the effect of reaction temperature and reaction pressure on this reaction have been studied on the catalyst NiO/MgO (Figs. 3c and 3d, Table S6 and S7). As with the increase of reaction temperature (from 50 ℃ to 200 ℃), the conversion of MA and selectivity of MMP were remarkably improved from 8.2% to 78.8% and 31.5–78.7%, respectively. This suggests that a higher reaction temperature was conductive to promote the conversion of MA and the selectivity of MMP. The optimal reaction temperature was 200 ℃ due to the highest selectivity of MMP. As with the increase of the reaction pressure from 0.1 MPa to 2 MPa, the conversion of MA and selectivity of MMP increased from 58.9% and 54.9–79.4% and 74.0%, respectively. While, as the reaction pressure increased from 2 MPa to 5 MPa, the conversion of MA and the selectivity of MMP remained stable basically. Then, the reaction pressure of 2 MPa was chosen for the subsequent evaluation in this research. Furthermore, the effect of different reaction time, MA content and amount of catalyst on the catalytic activities of NiO/MgO-4 were studied (Figs. 3e, 3f, 3g, Table S8, S9, S10). With the extension of reaction time, the conversion of MA and the selectivity of MMP increased gradually in the first 8 h (Fig. 3e, Table S8). While, the selectivity of MMP decreased to 63.5% when the reaction time reached 12 h. Additionally, in order to investigate the effect of the proportion of raw materials in the reaction, we increased the proportion of MA in the reactants (the total amount of reactants is fixed at 20 g). The conversion of MA and the selectivity of MMP increased firstly and then decreased with the increase of the proportion of MA (Fig. 3f, Table S9). The sequential product formation with MA towards MMP is based on the classic Michael addition reaction ( Scheme 1) [33]. When the amount of MA is out of a certain range in the reaction systems, 1,6-dimethoxy-5-(methoxymethyl)− 1,6-dioxohexan-2-ide anion is formed, and then a polymer is formed. The optimal MA amount was 20% according to the experiment. Besides, the optimal catalyst amount was 0.4 g for this reaction (Fig. 3g, Table S10). In order to explore the recyclability of catalyst, the recyclability of NiO/MgO-4 catalyst was tested three times in the addition reaction of MA with methanol (Fig. 3h, Table S11). After each time, the catalyst was separated from the product by centrifugation, and then the catalyst was washed by methanol and drying for at least 6 h. Then, the catalyst NiO/MgO-4 was reused without any other treatment. The conversion of MA and the selectivity of MMP remained stable basically after three cycles. Overall, the catalyst NiO/MgO-4 shows excellent catalytic activity and a good reusability for the addition reaction of methanol and MA to MMP. 3.3 Possible reaction mechanism The possible reaction mechanism ( Scheme 2) was proposed here based on the experiments in this work and the mechanism of cyanoethylation for alcohols over metal oxide catalysts reported by Hattori et al. [34]. From the XPS results (Fig. S1c), we can deduce that there are O2- ions on the NiO/MgO [23]. The O2- ions on the surface of the catalyst could act as basic sites. These ions are speculated to be beneficial for the abstracting of H+ from methanol [35]. The basic site abstracts an H+ from the hydroxyl group of methanol and then generate an alkoxide anion. Then, the alkoxy anion attacks the carbon cation of the CC bond of methyl acrylate and forms the methyl 3-methoxypropionate anion on the catalyst surface [35]. Finally, methyl 3-methoxypropionate anion extracted H+ to generate methyl 3-methoxypropionate. The addition reaction of MA and methanol to MMP are promoted by the catalyst NiO/MgO, which have abundant basic site. 4 Conclusions Methyl 3-methoxypropionate (MMP) was synthesized from addition reaction of methanol and methyl acrylate (MA). The NiO/MgO catalyst prepared by a direct-mixing method exhibits high activity in terms of yield and selectivity due to the suitable acidic and basic sites. Under the optimal conditions (200 °C, 2 MPa, 8 h, 0.4 g catalyst and mass ratio of MA/MeOH is 1:4) the conversion of MA was 79.0% and the selectivity of MMP was 90.6%. Further investigation indicates that the addition reaction of MeOH and MA is controlled by the optimal balance between acidic and basic sites. The basic sites would help to promote the transformation of MA. While, the acidic sites may promote the adsorption of MA dispersedly, and thus avoid the polymerization of MA and promote the selectivity of MMP. The NiO/MgO catalysts depict a promising prospect due to the efficient activity and good reusability for the addition reaction of methanol and MA to MMP. CRediT authorship contribution statement Guoqiang Xu and Zhou Lu conceived the research idea and were responsible for this study. Xiaoke Li performed the experiments and wrote the manuscript. Xiuyun Liu contributed to some characterization and discussion. coredata.dc:description: In this study, Methyl 3-methoxypropionate (MMP) was formed from the addition reaction of methyl acrylate (MA) and methanol using MO/MgO (M = Ce, Co, Ni) catalysts, which were prepared by a direct-mixing method. The prepared catalyst NiO/MgO shows good catalytic activity than that of the CeO/MgO and CoO/MgO under the same conditions. The characterization and catalytic activity evaluation indicate that the NiO content of NiO/MgO has a significant effect on the catalytic activity of the addition reaction by changing the acid-base properties of the catalyst. The synergistic effect of acidic and basic sites contributes to the addition reaction. The optimal reaction temperature and pressure for NiO/MgO on this addition reaction is 200 ℃ and 2 MPa, respectively (over 90% selectivity to MMP). The cycle test indicates that the NiO/MgO catalyst is highly recyclable.
coredata.dc:title: High-performance addition reaction of methyl acrylate and methanol for the preparation of Methyl 3-methoxypropionate on NiO/MgO catalyst
